chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In here, we will solve for the price per share of equity without considering the value for taxes.

In this problem, we will use the all-equity plan as the basis for the number of shares repurchased. To do this, we will simply take the number of shares for the all-equity plan then subtract the respective shares from Plan I and Plan II.

New shares outstanding:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New shares for Plan I}&=15,000-12,700\\[15 pt]
&=2,300\\[15 pt]
\text{New shares for Plan II}&=15,000-9,800\\[15 pt]
&=5,200
\end{aligned}$$


From this, we now have the new outstanding shares for Plan I which is $2,300$ and Plan II which is $5,200$

We can then solve for the equity price per share of the two plans by taking the total debt and dividing it by the number of outstanding shares.

For Plan I:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity Price per Share}&=\dfrac{\$109,250}{2,300}\\[15 pt]
&=\$47.50
\end{aligned}$$

For Plan II:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity Price per Share}&=\dfrac{\$247,000}{5,200}\\[15 pt]
&=\$47.50
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see, the equity price per share of the two plans are equal to $\$47.50$. This is because of the M&M theory that if there are no taxes, then the value of the company will not be affected by any capital structure.
